chapters.title: The Offer
chapters.summary: Disgraced textile conservator Elara Hughes receives a mysterious, too-good-to-be-true job offer to restore a unique artifact in rural Wales.
key_events: Elara is fired from a museum after a controversial restoration.
She receives a letter from the reclusive Llanfair Historical Trust, offering a huge sum for a private project.
The letter describes the 'Bride's Loom,' a 17th-century tapestry loom with woven panels, said to be a village treasure.
Desperate and intrigued, Elara accepts and travels to the remote village of Llanfair.
She is met by the stern trustee, Mr. Griffith, who gives her a terse welcome.
chapters.ending_hook: Elara is shown to a damp, stone outbuilding that will serve as her workshop. Inside, covered in a dusty sheet, sits the loom. The air feels unnaturally cold and still.

chapters.title: The First Thread
chapters.summary: Elara begins her assessment of the Bride's Loom and experiences the first unsettling phenomena.
key_events: Elara uncovers the loom. It is massive, made of blackened oak, with a half-woven tapestry still on the frame.
The tapestry depicts a stylized, twisting forest and a central, empty figure-shape.
The wool is miraculously preserved but the pattern is complex and unnerving, full of repeating, almost runic motifs.
As she touches a frayed thread to examine it, a sharp pain pricks her finger.
A drop of her blood soaks into the wool. That night, she dreams of a woman weaving in a dark room, whispering in Welsh.
She wakes to find the thread she touched has somehow repaired itself.
chapters.ending_hook: At the village pub, the locals fall silent when she enters. An old woman named Bronwyn slips her a note written in shaky English: 'The pattern is not art. It is a wall.'

chapters.title: Whispers in the Wool
chapters.summary: The restoration progresses strangely, and Elara starts investigating the loom's dark history against the villagers' wishes.
key_events: Elara finds she can repair the damaged sections with uncanny speed and precision, as if guided.
Each repaired section seems to make the tapestry 'darker,' the colors more vibrant and the patterns subtly shift.
She researches in the village's tiny archive, finding references to 'Mari Lwyd,' a 'Bridal Spirit,' and a pact made in 1623 after a series of disappearances.
Mr. Griffith warns her to stick to conservation, not superstition.
Elara hears faint whispering from the loom when she works alone, and finds threads seem to move of their own accord in her peripheral vision.
chapters.ending_hook: Examining the back of the tapestry under UV light, Elara sees faint, phosphorescent lines forming a new pattern—one that looks disturbingly like her own profile.

chapters.title: The Keeper of the Pact
chapters.summary: Elara confronts Bronwyn, who reveals the terrifying truth of the village's generational curse.
key_events: Elara seeks out Bronwyn, who lives in a cottage filled with protective charms (rowan crosses, iron nails).
Bronwyn explains: the entity is 'Gwraig y Lliain' (The Wife of the Linen), a jealous spirit bound to the loom by a ancestral pact.
The tapestry is not a decoration, but a prison wall. Its patterns are binding sigils.
Every generation, the loom must be maintained by an outsider—a skilled weaver or conservator—who becomes the 'Bride.'
Their final, completed stitch fully transfers the spirit's attachment to them, and they are taken, preserving the village for another lifetime.
The villagers are not her employers; they are her wardens.
chapters.ending_hook: Bronwyn shows Elara a parish record listing the names of past 'Brides,' all outsiders. The last entry is from 1965. The next line is blank. 'It waits for a name,' Bronwyn whispers. 'Your name.'

chapters.title: The Weaving Dream
chapters.summary: The entity's influence grows stronger, invading Elara's dreams and beginning to manipulate her waking actions.
key_events: Elara is plagued by vivid, possessive dreams where she *is* the entity, weaving its prison from the inside, feeling its ancient loneliness and rage.
She wakes with muscle memory of weaving motions, and finds new sections of the tapestry completed without her conscious effort.
She tries to leave Llanfair but her car won't start, and Mr. Griffith politely but firmly insists her contract requires completion.
The villagers now watch her with a mix of pity and grim expectation.
Elara attempts to deliberately damage the loom, but a wave of nausea and psychic pain stops her.
chapters.ending_hook: In a trance-like state, Elara sleepwalks to the workshop and weaves for hours. She wakes at dawn to find a large, completed section featuring a house that looks exactly like her childhood home.

chapters.title: A History of Blood
chapters.summary: Elara discovers the physical and brutal reality of the 'Bride' ritual, and that the villagers are prepared to enforce it.
key_events: Investigating the woods Bronwyn hinted at, Elara finds a moss-covered stone altar near a stream, stained with dark mineral deposits (or blood).
She is caught by Mr. Griffith and two other village men. The polite facade drops.
They confirm the ritual: when the tapestry is complete, the 'Bride' is traditionally bound in it and presented to the spirit at the altar.
Her body is never found. 'It is a sorrowful duty,' Griffith says, 'but our children sleep safe.'
Elara is now openly confined to her cottage and the workshop, a prisoner.
chapters.ending_hook: Desperate, Elara tries to burn a loose thread from the loom. It will not catch fire. Instead, the flame dies, and the thread coils around her wrist like a bracelet, cold and unbreakable.

chapters.title: Symbiosis
chapters.summary: Trapped, Elara is forced to continue the work, and feels the entity beginning to merge with her senses and memories.
key_events: The compulsion to weave is now a physical need; ignoring it causes migraines and bleeding from her nose.
As she weaves, she sees flashes of the entity's memories—a ancient grove, a betrayal, a binding ceremony.
She begins to understand snippets of the whispered Welsh.
The tapestry now clearly shows a narrative: a woman (the entity) being bound, then a procession of sacrificial brides, culminating in an unfinished figure.
Elara's own features are becoming more pronounced in that final figure.
chapters.ending_hook: Looking in a mirror, Elara sees, just for a second, another face superimposed over her own—a woman with eyes of spun wool and a smile of twisted thread.

chapters.title: The Run
chapters.summary: With Bronwyn's help, Elara makes a break for freedom, only to be thwarted by the entity's now vast influence over the land.
key_events: Bronwyn creates a distraction, allowing Elara to flee into the surrounding mountains.
The village does not pursue immediately, which is more frightening.
As night falls, the landscape itself seems to change. Paths Elara mapped lead in circles.
Trees take on the shapes of figures from the tapestry.
She hears the rhythmic *clack-clack* of a phantom loom echoing through the valleys.
Exhausted and lost, she stumbles into a clearing—right before the stone altar.
chapters.ending_hook: Standing at the altar is a semi-transparent figure of a woman in a tattered bridal gown, silently pointing back toward Llanfair. The message is clear: there is no escape. Her fate is woven.

chapters.title: The Final Pattern
chapters.summary: Resigned, Elara returns to the loom, now understanding she must complete it, but plots to subvert the pattern from within.
key_events: Elara returns to the workshop. The villagers watch, silent and solemn.
She studies the foundational weave of the prison-sigils, taught by the entity's own memories now in her mind.
She realizes a flaw: the ritual requires the Bride's *willing* completion. True despair or resistance could fray the final binding.
She begins to weave the final panel, which will name her. But she starts to subtly alter the ancient pattern, weaving in a symbol of decay (moth) and release (broken thread) from her own training.
The entity senses this and fights her, causing physical pain and terrifying visions.
chapters.ending_hook: As she weaves her own name into the border, the entity's whispers become a deafening roar in her mind. The loom shakes violently. The final thread must be her own hair, and she is compelled to cut it.

chapters.title: The Naming
chapters.summary: Elara completes the tapestry, triggering the final ritual. The entity begins its transfer.
key_events: With the last thread (a strand of her hair) woven in, the tapestry is complete. It glows with a sickly, internal light.
The villagers, led by Griffith, enter the workshop. They are in ceremonial dress.
They carefully cut the tapestry from the loom. It is heavy, impossibly so.
Elara is seized and wrapped in the completed tapestry. The world shifts; she can feel the ancient spirit pouring into her, a flood of cold, possessive consciousness.
She is carried in a procession to the stone altar in the woods.
chapters.ending_hook: Bound in the woolen prison, Elara feels her own identity being smothered. At the altar, Griffith raises an ancient shearing knife, not to kill her, but to ceremonially 'cut her free' from this world. The entity's triumph is imminent.

chapters.title: The Unraveling
chapters.summary: In the climactic moment, Elara enacts her sabotage, using her knowledge as a conservator to destroy from within.
key_events: As the ritual chant reaches its peak, Elara focuses not on fighting the entity, but on the flawed symbol she wove.
She concentrates all her will on the concept of *unmaking*, of conservation in reverse—the moth, the broken thread.
The tapestry binding her begins to itch, then burn. The threads of her sabotage vibrate.
From the point of her woven symbol, a rapid unraveling begins, not of the physical wool, but of the spiritual binding pattern.
The entity shrieks in her mind and in the physical world, a sound of tearing fabric and wind.
The altar stone cracks. The villagers recoil in horror.
chapters.ending_hook: The tapestry explodes outward in a blast of spectral thread and dust. Elara is thrown free. The entity, neither fully bound nor fully free, manifests as a raging, fragmented vortex of wool and shadow above the altar.

chapters.title: The New Weave
chapters.summary: In the aftermath, a new and terrible balance is struck, leaving Elara forever changed and the curse transformed.
key_events: The vortex-entity, unbound from its prison but now anchored to the *damaged* pattern, is not released into the world. Instead, it is trapped in a broken, furious state around the altar glade.
The curse is not broken, but shattered. The village is no longer safe; the entity's rage now touches them all, their protection gone.
Elara, her hair now stark white and her eyes holding a flicker of the loom's pattern, stands. She is free, but part of the entity's essence is forever tangled with her soul.
She walks past the terrified villagers, who are now prisoners in their own haunted valley.
She takes one thing: the ancient shearing knife, a tool of both bondage and release.
chapters.ending_hook: On a train leaving Wales, Elara looks at her reflection. Sometimes, she sees the other face. She opens her portfolio; inside is a single, perfect thread of impossibly dark wool. She knows two things: she understands textiles now on a level no one else does, and somewhere, in the back of her mind, a phantom loom continues to weave. The work is never truly finished.
